title: Get Out of Your Own Way

description.plain:
This is U2’s second official single from Songs of Experience. It was released on November 1, 2017.

U2 once again teams up with American rapper Kendrick Lamar, making this their second collaboration of 2017. The two artists had previously worked together on the song  “XXX” from Kendrick’s album, DAMN.. On the song, Bono of U2 sings the chorus, and The Edge, Adam Clayton, and Larry Mullen Jr. have writing credits on the song as well.

title: Walk On By

description.plain:
“Walk on By” is the third single off Thundercat’s Drunk. It was released on February 22, two days before the album.

The song features Compton-born rapper and close collaborator Kendrick Lamar. The pair collaborated previously on Kendrick’s critically-acclaimed LP To Pimp A Butterfly – Thundercat was credited as a featuring artist on “Wesley’s Theory” and single “These Walls.”

On the track, Thundercat considers the weight of loneliness whilst Kendrick shoulders the weight of the “wrongs” he’s trying to right.

The song speaks of external pressure, self-betterment and believing in one’s self when others don’t and touches on a multitude of other tidbits.

It’s produced by Pete Rahk.

title: Heaven & Hell

description.plain:
The first verse of this song describes all of the qualities of life that are evil, negative, and representative of Hell-on-Earth, while the second half describes the aspects of life that are good, positive and representative of Kendrick’s paradise.

The second half verse is significantly shorter than the first, this is intentionally done to allude to the fact that there is more evil in the world than good.

title: 100 Favors

description.plain: In the mixtape version of this song, Detail really stole the show. He sang each chorus more emotionally than the previous, and he had a much longer intro with a bridge. Sadly, those were all cut in the album version. Birdman also had an extended verse, but it was shortened in the album version to make room for Kendrick Lamar’s verse at the end.

title: Night of the Living Junkies

description.plain:
“Night of the Living Junkies” is the third track on the original tracklist for Kendrick Lamar’s fourth solo mixtape, Overly Dedicated. It was produced by longtime TDE collaborator Sounwave, who interpolates Kanye West’s August 2004 track “The New Workout Plan.”

Possibly due to copyright issues stemming from use of this sample, the song is omitted from the commercial release of Overly Dedicated, as well as tracklists found on streaming platforms such as Spotify or Tidal.

title: Kendrick Lamar’s Interlude

description.plain: This is the sequel to “Ab-Soul’s Outro” from Section.80. It features similar production, notably with the exact same cymbal riff in the background of the song. Kendrick’s flow is based directly off Soulo’s on “Ab-Soul’s Outro.” Many of the lyrics are also similar to those found on the 2011 collaboration between these two Black Hippy members.

title: Wanna Be Heard

description.plain:
“Wanna be Heard” is the sixth track off of The Kendrick Lamar – EP.

The song displays a then relatively-unknown, even hungrier Lamar, whose masterful storytelling and mixture of clever braggadocio with humble honesty is hard not to relate to.

The production is handled by Detroit underground legend Black Milk, his first and only collaboration with Lamar.

title: Phone Home

description.plain:
“Phone Home” serves as the seventh track on Kendrick Lamar’s third solo mixtape, C4—inspired by Lil Wayne’s June 2008 album, Tha Carter III. This song is a remix of Lil Wayne’s “Phone Home” and features Terrence “Punch” Henderson, the president of Top Dawg Entertainment.

The track is produced by Cool & Dre. In a June 2008 interview with XXL Magazine, the duo discussed producing the original for Lil Wayne:

[Dre and I] wanted to do a record that reflects that [Wayne’s] a rock star from outer space. The whole concept was that there’s no real rappers left in the game and the ‘hood is calling him home. We actually had like 19 people [play on it]. We had trombones, violins, horns, and then we tripled them and made them sound real big.

title: I Do This

description.plain:
Recorded in 2009, Kendrick Lamar’s “I Do This” is a boastful realization of his success as an artist. Fellow TDE labelmate and Black Hippy artist, Jay Rock tags along with Lamar, who floats on a Sounwave-produced beat that samples Bill Withers‘ 1975 track, “Don’t You Want To Stay?”

During an August 2010 performance of “I Do This,” Kendrick talked about the song:

This song don’t only represent energy and attitude, but it represents mothafuckin' confidence…

In April 2016, Lamar was sued over the Bill Withers sample, which hadn’t been cleared. According to the lawsuit, “I Do This” was viewed as a direct copy:

The musical composition of ‘I Do This’ consists of nothing more than new, so-called Rap or Hip Hop lyrics, set to the existing music of ‘Don’t You Want to Stay.'

title: A Milli (Freestyle)

description.plain:
“A Milli (Freestyle)” is the fourth track from Kendrick Lamar’s third mixtape, C4, a project inspired by Lil Wayne’s 2008 album, Tha Carter III. On the track, Kendrick raps over the beat of Wayne’s hit single “A Milli,” and speaks about his importance in the rap game.

Kendrick and Wayne would later meet up and officially collaborate on Wayne’s 2018 song “Mona Lisa.”

title: Today

description.plain:
Kendrick released this song on October 1, 2009 when he had recently changed his stage name from K.Dot to Kendrick Lamar. It served as a warm-up for his self-titled EP released on December 31, 2009, but it was not featured on the final release.

This is the original version of the song. Kendrick re-recorded this song in 2010 with the same beat and chorus, but a completely new first verse and alternate takes on the second and third verses. The original version features rougher, more aggressive vocals in the style Kendrick used when he was known as K.Dot, while the second version was performed with a more relaxed delivery.

The song features frequent TDE collaborator JaVonte on the hook, and supporting vocals from Alori Joh.

title: West Coast Wu-Tang

description.plain:
“West Coast Wu-Tang” serves as the sixth track to Kendrick Lamar’s third solo mixtape, C4. The song features fellow Black Hippy member, Ab-Soul, and includes a guest verse from Terrence “Punch” Henderson, who is the president of Top Dawg Entertainment.

K-Dot pays homage to the Staten Island collective Wu-Tang Clan by sampling Wendy Rene’s August 1964 track, “After Laughter (Comes Tears).” RZA of the Wu-Tang Clan used the same sample on 1994’s “Tearz” off of their debut album, Enter the Wu-Tang.

In a November 2011 interview with the radio station 90.5FM KSJS, Lamar spoke on Wu-Tang’s influence in his music and career:

Just that raw element of hip-hop, you know. To do what I want to do, and to have my own voice. That was a group of individuals that had each individual sound. Nobody sounded like each other, and everybody went for self and did what they wanted to do. And that’s hip-hop. Being yourself and expressing yourself.

title: Father Stretch (Kendrick Lamar Demo)

description.plain:
On March 18, 2018, an eight-second snippet of Kendrick Lamar and Kanye West rapping over the “Father Stretch My Hands, Pt. 1” instrumental was leaked by a group known as MusicLeaks. The full song later leaked on March 23.

Kendrick has more of a pivotal role in the song than Kanye, and it’s possible that his verse serves as a reference for Kanye in the same manner as his “All Day” verse.

“Let Us Move On” is a song by English singer Dido. It features the vocals from American rapper Kendrick Lamar. The song was released as a promotional single.

title: The New Cupid

description.plain:
BJ the Chicago Kid and Kendrick Lamar link up once again. This time for “The New Cupid,” a song about how love slowly is being replaced by one night stands. ‘Cupid’ spends more time in the club nowadays then he spreads love.

BJ The Chicago Kid and Kendrick also collaborated on the song called “His Pain II” from BJ’s first album Pineapple Now-Laters,  and on several songs from Kendrick’s projects before good kid, m.A.A.d city.

The song samples Raphael Saadiq’s “Oh Girl,” and BJ told Genius in an annotation that Saadiq is actually on the recording as well.

The textured beat also contains some classic ‘70s Soul samples. Listen for the vocal sample from “Mr. Big Stuff” by Jean Knight and the drums from “Walk On By” by Isaac Hayes.

title: Vanity Slave Pt. 2

description.plain:
Kendrick released this song online on February 1, 2011. The song served as a warm-up for his Section.80 album released later in the year. However, the song was not featured on the final release.

The song is a sequel to “Vanity Slaves” from on the Kendrick Lamar EP, and discusses how society is negatively influenced by consumerism.

Gucci Mane’s contribution is a sample, and he did not record specifically for the song.

Produced by Sounwave

title: Bad Blood (Remix) (Taylor’s Version)

description.plain:
“Bad Blood (Remix) (Taylor’s Version)” is the bonus song to the deluxe version of “1989 (Taylor’s Version)”, which is the re-recorded version to Taylor’s “1989. This song features Compton rapper Kendrick Lamar, who is the sole featured artist of the album.

This song is considered to be the public note to the public by Taylor Swift on her falling with Katy Perry. Meanwhile, Kendrick raps about his thoughts on his hater.

Kendrick’s verse on this version of the song is also different from the original version.

title: Shock the World

description.plain:
J. Cole and Kendrick Lamar team up on “Shock The World,” a warning shot to everyone who doubted them. On the BJ the Chicago Kid assisted track, the artists boast about their imminent takeover of the rap game and describe their attempt to build a legacy.

Rumors surrounding a collaborative album have persisted since 2010 and this track teases its release. The album never released, however, and the two have only collaborated multiple times since.

title: Abortion Money

description.plain:
“Abortion Money” originally leaked as a 2024 song titled “Hollywood” before being debunked as a song from 2019 titled under the current title. Featuring vocals from from an unknown female singer, the song was updated throughout 2020 and became one of the versions of “Somebody” at some point.

A YouTube upload was taken down by Sergiu Gherman, who has worked with Kendrick before, likely suggesting that this is another song produced by him.

The song interpolates “Things Behind The Sun” by Nick Drake. This song is produced by Bēkon, Sounwave & Sergiu Gherman.

title: Mr. Carter

description.plain:
“Mr. Carter” serves as the third track to Kendrick Lamar’s third solo mixtape, C4, inspired by Lil Wayne’s sixth studio album, Tha Carter III.  Produced by Infamous and Drew Correa, this song is a remix of Wayne’s “Mr. Carter,” and features an additional verse from the New Orleans rapper.

In a 2012 interview with Civil TV, Lamar spoke on being acknowledged by one of his influencers:

For [Lil Wayne] to actually acknowledge what I’m doing right now and seeing it as a path, the same way the longevity he created, it’s a great feeling to share that same stage and a moment with him. Wayne ain’t no new jack to this game. He influenced a lot of styles and a lot of sounds. I would say I was influenced by a certain sound and flow and cadence that he brought to the game.

title: Compton Chemistry

description.plain:
“Compton Chemistry” serves as the eighth track on Kendrick Lamar’s third solo mixtape, C4—inspired by Lil Wayne’s June 2008 album, Tha Carter III. This song is a remix of Lil Wayne’s “Dr. Carter,” and features fellow Black Hippy artist, Ab-Soul. On the track, Lamar educates Ab-Soul on cooking cocaine.

The track is produced by Swizz Beatz. In a June 2008 interview with XXL Magazine, the producer said about the original:

It was a concept that could have either been for Wayne or Jay-Z.  It definitely fit Wayne. He’s representing the next generation and he delivered on it.

title: For the Homies

description.plain:
For the HOMIES

Kendrick released this song online on July 30, 2010. It served as a warm-up for his Overly Dedicated mixtape released later in the year, but it was not featured on the final release.

The content of the song describes the day-to-day lifestyle and activities of his friends.

The song is a sequel to the track “For the Girlfriends”, which was released on December 22, 2009 as a warm-up for the Kendrick Lamar EP.

Produced by Sounwave

title: Better Off

description.plain:
A song about the dissolution of a relationship, with both parties questioning whether they’d be better off without each other.

Both members of Quadron were part of Boom Clap Bachelors, whose “Tiden Flyver” was sampled to create Kendrick’s “Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe.” According to Robin, the producer half of the duo:

We only have one feature on our new album, and we are elated that it’s Kendrick Lamar. He invited us to collaborate on his own album, and we had such a great time working with him that we asked him if he wanted to be part of our project as well. We are so happy for all his success and we are very proud of this song. We wanted to have more of a fluid song that wasn’t too over structured and had a bit of a bedroom/after hours vibe to it.”

title: K104 Halloween Freestyle

description.plain:
This freestyle rap captures the essence of a confident and charismatic artist asserting their dominance in the rap game. With clever wordplay and a relentless flow, the artist boasts about their skills and accomplishments while also touching on various cultural and political topics. From references to iconic figures like Biggie and Pac to playful jabs at contemporary figures like Mitt Romney and Kim Kardashian, the song showcases the artist’s ability to effortlessly blend humor, social commentary, and bravado.

Set against a backdrop of Halloween imagery and pop culture references, the artist paints a vivid picture of their world, where they reign supreme as the “ruler of the game.” Whether they’re soaring to the moon with witches or smacking pumpkins across heads, the artist exudes confidence and wit, captivating listeners with their lyrical prowess. With nods to current events like Hurricane Sandy and the Lakers, the song feels both timeless and timely, offering a snapshot of the artist’s mindset and the cultural landscape of the time.

title: Hustla’s Story

description.plain:
“Hustla’s Story” is the second track on Dreamville signee Cozz' album Effected. It was released as a single on Feb. 13, 2018 and features fellow LA-based rapper Kendrick Lamar.

This marks the duo’s first collaboration. This collaboration happened by chance: Cozz bumped into Kendrick at the Interscope studio and told him he was working on his album and asked for him to come and listen to it. Kendrick heard this beat and jumped on it.

title: Little Johnny

description.plain: “Little Johnny” is the 13th track of the Unreleased Mixtape (2011) and track 5 in The Compton 1987 Compilation. In this cut, Kendrick takes the listener through his hometown of Compton, California, and contemplates if he’ll be able to survive to age 25. Later on, he tells the story of Jonathan, a young gangster that falls victim to the gang culture in Compton. The ending of Jonathan’s story is revealed on Kid Cudi’s “Solo Dolo Part II” here.

description.plain:
Following on from high profile leaks such as the Kendrick/Lady Gaga collab and unreleased Drake tracks, this collaboration between Dre, Kendrick and Jeremih leaked 24 May, 2015. It is a smooth love song presumably from the sessions for Dre’s highly anticipated album formerly titled Detox.

The beat was sampled from The Roots‘ “You Got Me”.

title: Money Without Me

description.plain:
“Money Without Me” is an unreleased song by Kendrick Lamar. Throughout the track, Kendrick reflects on his ambition, personal growth, success, and frustration with artificial relationships. In addition, Lamar emphasizes his determination to achieve financial independence and “walk the walk” or “be about it,” all while declaring that other people are dependent on him and not vice versa.

The song was recorded sometime in 2011 during the sessions for Lamar’s debut album, Section.80, but was ultimately excluded from the final tracklist. The song was first previewed on December 10, 2022 by a seller on an Internet forum, and was leaked in its entirety on December 16, 2022.

On December 17, 2024, the song was uploaded to Lamar’s YouTube channel. The cover art featured the same 1987 Buick GNX shown on the cover of Lamar’s sixth album, November 2024’s GNX, causing speculation that the song served as a teaser for a deluxe edition of the album. One day later, the song was struck with a copyright claim by Universal Music Group and taken down due to it being an unofficial release. The song was uploaded again on December 26, 2024 alongside the 2008 song “World Negatives” as part of an unofficial EP titled FAITH, but both songs were taken down later that day.

title: I Am Somebody

description.plain:
“I Am Somebody” is an unreleased track from rapper Kendrick Lamar.

The track was recorded in early 2023 during the sessions for Lamar’s sixth studio album, GNX.

An unfinished version of the track was leaked in its entirety on June 21, 2024, and it is currently unknown whether the song will ever see an official release.

This song was originally recorded back in 2022 for Kendrick’s Mr. Morale album but was later left off and given to Sampha. This version seems to have more developed production with the addition to a synth that was not present in Kendrick’s version and the inclusion of Sampha’s own vocals now.

This version of the song would leak on January 16, 2023.

title: Loved Ones

description.plain:
Loved ones comes from a 2018 leak from the rapper Kendrick Lamar.  The origins of the leak are unknown, but fans came to title the leak “Bad Kid Chill City” as an homage to Kendrick Lamar’s Good kid Maad City.  The leak was 8 songs long, but was followed by another leak of Lamar’s music label, Top Dawg Entertainment.  The leak included songs, demos, and remixes from SZA, ScHoolboy Q, Jay Rock, Isaiah Rashad, Ab Soul, and others.  This song is believed to have been recorded while Kendrick was working on To Pimp a Butterfly, because of its production.  Lamar’s vocals were later removed from the track, and the instrumentals were repurposed for Jay Rock’s album, Redemption, as the title track.

In the song, Lamar reflects on moments of his childhood with those that are no longer with him.  He wishes he could go back to that simpler time.  Lamar specifically mentions in the song his friend’s little brother Chad Keaton, and his friend known as Pat Dawg, names he has mentioned before in other songs.

title: Don’t Wanna Know (Extended Version)

description.plain:
“Don’t Wanna Know” is a song about past lovers. Adam focuses on not wanting to know what his ex-lover has been up to or who she’s been with since they broke up, while Kendrick shows his ex what she’s been missing.

The extended version of the original “Don’t Wanna Know” features a new Kendrick Lamar verse at the start of the song. “Don’t Wanna Know (Extended Version)” is played on the radio through CHR, Rhythmic, and Urban radio formats.

title: Blood Sport (Freestyle)

description.plain:
On “Blood Sport (Freestyle),” Kendrick Lamar was still rapping under the K-Dot moniker, when he was known for his extensive use of “murder bars”—particularly sports and pop culture references which double as insults against his opposition.

The beat used for this song comes from JAY-Z’s iconic “Show Me What You Got,” the first single off of November 2006’s Kingdom Come.

title: Picture Me Rollin’ (Remix)

description.plain:
Kendrick’s remix to 2pac’s Picture Me Rollin.

Kendrick has been compared a lot to 2pac because they both grew up in Compton and both focus on political and meaningful rap styles. They also are both incredible word smiths and are the smart, well meaning kids who grew up in a rough area and want to make a change.

This was released shortly after Kendrick’s grammy award winning ‘To Pimp A Butterfly’ when the comparisons were more prevalent than ever.

title: G Code

description.plain:
Kendrick (then K. Dot)’s 2009 mixtape “C4”, which is inspired by Lil’ Wayne’s 2008 album “Tha Carter 3 ”, comprising mostly of freestyles over instrumentals from Wayne’s original album (in addition to a number of original tracks). Kendrick’s re-imagination of Wayne’s album is a very insightful listen into the evolution of his style, as well as drawing up an interesting comparison between the two artists.
(The beat Kendrick borrows for this song originally comes from Wayne’s song “Let the Beat Build”, produced by KanYe West.)

title: Make Me Happy

description.plain:
This is a Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers era song recorded sometime in May 2020 that leaked in full online on December 15, 2022. It was likely originally intended for the album at some point but never made it to the released version.

This song includes several lyrics that were later reused in “Purple Hearts.”

The song also includes the following variation of a lyric from the 2020 pgLang Mission Statement: “Too many opinions in a glasshouse, this world I don’t know, no more need to cash out.”

title: Overthink / Tranquilizer

description.plain:
This is a Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers era song recorded sometime in May 2020 that leaked in full online on December 16, 2022. It was meant for the May 2020 version of Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers before the version was scrapped. This version of the song was originally known by fans as “Therapy Session #9” but the official title is “Tranquilizer.”

This song is partially a demo of “United in Grief.” The first part of the song is mostly identical in lyrics and production to the first part of United in Grief, but the second parts on each track differ entirely.

title: Click Clack

description.plain:
“Click Clack” is an unreleased collaboration between Kendrick Lamar and Bruno Mars, recorded on the 3rd of June 2011, intended for Section.80.

Bruno Mars' chorus was used for Diggy Simmon’s song “Click Clack Away”, which was released in May 2011.

A snippet of the song surfaced on the 29th of April 2023. The entire song leaked on the 5th of May 2023.

title: Shot Down

description.plain:
“Shot Down” is the tenth track from Kendrick Lamar’s third mixtape, C4, a project inspired by Lil Wayne’s 2008 album, Tha Carter III. On the track, Kendrick raps over the beat of Wayne’s track “Shoot Me Down” and speaks about forgiveness for various sins he’s committed.

Kendrick and Wayne would later meet up and officially collaborate on Wayne’s 2018 song “Mona Lisa.”

title: Who Shot Ya (Freestyle)

description.plain: This Freestyle was sampled over Christopher Wallace AKA Notorious BIG’s famous song Who Shot Ya, a supposed diss towards Tupac Shakur (Kendrick’s biggest idol, and a west coast rapper who lived in Compton) after he was shot in New York in 1994. Wallace and Junior Mafia claim that the song was written and recorded before the shooting that almost killed Tupac, therefore it was not aimed at him.

title: The Prayer

description.plain:
On “The Prayer” Kendrick Lamar reflects over “the voices of art” and personifies a song by Michael Jackson and a speech by Martin Luther King, Jr., respectively. In each of the first two verses, Lamar mentions two dates that relate to the lives of each man—The Jackson 5’s “ABC” released on February 24, 1970, and MLK delivered his “I Have A Dream” speech on August 28, 1963.

Kendrick uses every verse to explore how the media is quick to dismiss an artist’s contributions to society due to their personal shortcomings—he specifically delves into Jackson’s pedophilia accusations and King’s marital infidelity. In the final verse, Kendrick establishes that artists bring meaning to the world regardless of their individual imperfections.

The song was recorded sometime in 2019. Leaked on August 18th, 2020, under the name “Prayer”, however it was only ever titled “Pray” and “Mr. Morale”. Ultimately scrapped due to being leaked along with “Gotta Love Me” and “Somebody.”. Also mistakenly thought to be an original version of “The Heart Part 5”.

Lyrics for the song were present on Tidal for “Mr. Morale” when the song first released before being changed. Zaytop claimed that this was meant to show up on the album as the title track but it was replaced with the version produced by Pharrell Williams.

title: Vent (Crown Demo)

description.plain: One of the songs that was meant for the May 2020 version of this album. Not the final name of the song. This song is unrelated to the Kendrick and Keem collab, they just use the same name. Snippet posted on leaked.cx on October, 20, 2021 along with 5 other snippets. Very low quality snippet recorded from a car stereo. Features Eckhart Tolle’s “Auntie Diaries” intro and original lyrics that didn’t make it to the released version, most of which are about his uncle who passed away from cancer. Samples “Through The Night” by Duval Timothy. Extended snippet leaked by zaytop on October 10, 2023 and revealed to be another idea to “vent”.

title: Don’t Jump (Demo)

description.plain:
“Don’t Jump” is an unreleased collaboration between Kanye West and Kendrick Lamar that was most likely recorded during their sessions recording over Madlib beats.

The first snippet of the song was released by the group known as Music Leaks on March 18, 2018. The song was later previewed in full via a Periscope stream on March 23 before leaking in full-quality later that night.

album: All Rize To Tha Top (Digital Bonus Version)

description.plain:
TDE co-president Punch drops another record on his Soundcloud. Already the sixth one – the #MyProjectWindow tag could be a hint to an album.

Kendrick Lamar is featured on the song, but uncredited and he only performs the hook. The song is like a lot of Punch his other songs about living (or getting out) the projects/ghetto. It’s also a homage to Tupac – who died aged 25, he is sampled and many lines refer/allude to him.

title: Cross-Trainers

description.plain:
Like (of Pac Div) produced the first half of “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst” off of Kendrick Lamar’s good kid, m.A.A.d city, and this is, presumably, another little something that came of their studio session.

The collaboration also features Johnson Barnes, making it a truly west coast affair. Apparently Kendrick has no care for the beef between Blu and labelmate Schoolboy Q.

The song hit the internet on Tuesday, November 6, 2012, prior to the release of Pac Div’s GMB, of  which it is a part of.

title: Eyes Above (Remix)

description.plain:
While we await the release of the track, Flying Lotus recently played a joint with Kendrick on it at a recent concert. Kendrick glides over a soothing vocal sample and some powerful drums, with the style eerily similar to that of songs of Kanye West’s last release Yeezus, for which he went on tour for.




Update: Turns out that the song is a remix to “Eyes Above” and a studio quality version of the song will not be released due to “political reasons”.

title: One Of You

description.plain:
‘One Of You’ is a 2019 unreleased song by N.E.R.D, Kendrick Lamar & André 3000.

The song was an N.E.R.D song likely from NO ONE EVER REALLY DIES that Kendrick picked up and added a verse onto.

The song shares 2 lines with ‘Count Me Out’ the opening song from Kendrick Lamar’s 2022 record ‘Mr Morale & The Big Steppers’

title: Ain’t That Funkin’ Kinda Hard on You? (Louie Vega Remix)

description.plain: The long-awaited George Clinton X Kendrick Lamar team-up is here. Clinton enlists the rapper for a sped-up, jacked-up remix to “Ain’t That Funkin' Kinda Hard On You?” from Funkadelic’s 2014 album First Ya Gotta Shake the Gate. Kendrick and George have previously collaborated “Wesley’s Theory”, the opening song of Lamar’s album To Pimp A Butterfly.

title: PARTYNAUSEOUS (Demo)

description.plain:
This song was a collaboration initially meant for the album good Kid, m.A.A.d city, but due to creative differences, the track was cut. It was later repurposed by Gaga as an interlude during her ARTPOP tour.

The original version of the track – or at least the one with Kendrick on it – was leaked online May 20, 2015.

Hitta J3 manages to recruit Problem, Kendrick Lamar and YG for the “Do Yo Gudda” remix.

Compton rapper Hitta J3 dropped a mixtape called The Wake Up Call in October 2013, which contained “Do Yo Gudda”

Today the upcoming rapper returns to “Do Yo Gudda” enlisting fellow West Coast natives Problem, Kendrick Lamar and YG to hop on the record.

title: American Skin (41 Shots)

description.plain:
Mary J. Blige and Kendrick Lamar’s version of “American Skin (41 Shots)” uses Bruce Springsteen’s song of the same name as the backbone, while Kendrick adds a new verse. The song, like the original, speaks about the injustice and racism among American law enforcement.

Springsteen’s version was released 15 years prior, but the lyrics are just as relevant to today’s society—if not more. With the recent killing of Terrence Crutcher, among many others, and  police shootings continuing to increase, the song comes at a time of need—another anthem for the African-American population.

title: Money Over Love

description.plain:
In anticipation of the neo soul singer’s new album In Another Life, BBC Radio 6 legend Gilles Peterson played a collection of Bilal classics in mid-June. The set included a long snippet of “Money Over Love” featuring Kendrick Lamar and Adrian Younge. Prior to this, the song was only known from live performances in May.

The full track was released online June 22, 2015, one week ahead of the release of the album.

title: Want U 2 Want

description.plain:
Want U 2 Want is a song that was premiered on the Beats 1 Radio on Apple Music under Q-Tip’s time slot, Abstract Radio.

There have been no further details to an official release date or any further information about any future Kendrick Lamar and Q-Tip work.

Kendrick collaborated with Q-Tip’s A Tribe Called Quest group back in 2016, for “Conrad Tokyo”, off their politically charged sixth studio album.

During an interview, Q-Tip stated Kendrick’s music was a direct influence on Tribe’s album;

Like we were listening to ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ by Queen, then ‘Money Trees’ by Kendrick and then we’d go to like Rakim. It was just a sonic exercise to hear all of those different records, not to geek out but to hear the common thread, sonically.

title: Watch Yo Lady

description.plain:
On “Watch Yo Lady,” Carson rapper Ab-Soul and Kendrick Lamar team up to warn the opposition about their skills with the ladies. They trade bars about superior intellect and expensive jewelry, in addition to tackling more meaningful topics, such as police brutality.

This track marks the third joint effort between the two TDE labelmates on Ab-Soul’s Long Term project. They also collaborated on “Blow Them Horns II” and “Day in the Life.” They had previously worked together on several tracks from Kendrick’s C4 project, which was also released in January of 2009.

title: Still Hustlin’

description.plain:
“Still Hustlin'” serves as the 13th track on Kendrick Lamar’s third solo mixtape, C4—inspired by Lil Wayne’s June 2008 album, Tha Carter III. This song is a remix of Wayne’s “La La,” and features TDE labelmates and Black Hippy artists, Ab-Soul and Jay Rock.

The track is produced by David Banner. In a June 2008 interview with XXL Magazine, Banner revealed that the original beat was intended for the Shrek the Third Soundtrack:

I actually did that beat for the Shrek 3 soundtrack. I got a call at the last moment by my movie agent and they were having a problem with one of the tracks on Shrek 3 and needed a track. It was going to be an instrumental or a song, but either way it wasn’t designed for a rapper.

title: Computer Love (DRONES Demo)

description.plain: A reference track created in mid-2015 or 2016 appropriately mirroring the popular 1986 Zapp & Roger song of the same name, this song was made as a reference track during the sessions for DAMN. with Kendrick revisiting funk production reminiscent of To Pimp a Butterfly. While this song appeared to never be intended for official release, it leaked in full in early 2023 apart of an unofficial three-song EP named the Morale Pack.

title: Butterfly

description.plain:
“Butterfly” is a currently unreleased collaboration between Kendrick Lamar and Ed Sheeran that was supposedly recorded during the DAMN. era of Kendrick’s career.

The title likely references Kendrick’s March 2015 album To Pimp A Butterfly, which discussed social justice themes and was uplifting to the African American community.

title: Sexy Pause

description.plain:
This song is a DAMN. era throwaway that leaked in full on March 2, 2023. It shares the same instrumental as ScHoolboy Q’s “Dope Dealer,” likely given to Q after Kendrick opted not to make anything further of this demo. The instrumental samples “Playa Hataz” by Three 6 Mafia.

ScHoolboy Q used the song as a reference track based on a single line on the pre-chorus.

While a reputable source suggests it was created in 2018, Alek claims it was developed in 2019 during the same period as “Vent,” “Fix Of Heart,” and “Park,” with possible additional work done in 2023. title: You Don’t Like

description.plain:
You Don’t Like ft. Kendrick Lamar and Alex was released in 2012 on Melo Kan’s mixtape entitled “Mama’s Only Sun”.

The song is your typical I-finally-made-it  rap song that every rapper seems to be releasing at an attempt to sound remotely intelligent but Kendrick Lamar kills it on this track, much like he kills it on every track he’s featured on. The song’s got a sick beat and a very catchy hook.

Produced by: 1500 or Nothin'

title: Lift Me Up (Remix)

description.plain:
Remix released by DJ Ill Will on the one year anniversary of the release of Jay Rock’s ‘Lift Me Up’.

There is a common misconception that this track is a Black Hippy remix, but the version circulated that can be found on the popular fan made Black Hippy mixtape is actually just an edit of this song. That version is actually incorrect too as it has Roccett’s verse on the song instead of ScHoolboy Q’s.

The original track is rare but can be heard here: https://my.mail.ru/music/search/L%20Boy%20Feat%20Glasses%20Malone%2C%20Jah%20Free%20%26amp%3B%20Jay%20Rock

title: What’s My Name (Remix)

description.plain:
This live remix of Prince’s “What’s My Name” was revealed on May 5th, only two weeks after Prince’s death. The performance is from 2014’s album release party of both Plectrumelectrum and Art Official Age.

The collaboration may be seen as unexpected, however, Kendrick recorded songs with the music legend for To Pimp A Butterfly, none of which made the final cut.

Lamar spoke about his time in the studio with Prince on Hot 97:

I didn’t trip over getting a song done. I really appreciate the actual game he was giving me. He took control of his music. He was breaking down some things that I need to consider in my career. What [Jay Z] is doing is just confirmation from what Prince was telling me.

title: Mother (Mother I Sober Demo)

description.plain:
The earliest version of Mother I Sober, also referred to as “Somebody” or “For Me,” shares very little in common with the final release aside from the lyrics of the chorus. While the final song explores the far reaching effects of sexual assault through a story of his mother, this version of the song finds Kendrick much more hopeless in both his lyrics and delivery. Here is asking far more questions than he is giving answers, like he would on Disc 2 of Mr. Morale.

Instead of telling the world his solutions, he nearly gives in and admitting and he considers walking away from the fame, and in a much more crushing way than on Mirror.

Now while his sentiments may be different, putting the pieces together shows how he was able to evolve these thoughts into the strongest points of the final album.

title: Manchester Freestyle Cypher Verses (2016)

description.plain: In March 2016, Kendrick Lamar made an appearance for Reebok Classic in Manchester, UK. Kendrick went to a Hip Hop Workshop session featuring 40 young musicians, hosted by Brighter Sounds and The Wonder Inn as well as Reebok. He decided to freestyle battle and cypher with some of the young talent, giving them a surprise they never expected.

title: Tranquilizer

description.plain:
Originally, “Tranquilizer” was a leaked song titled, “Therapy Session #9” attached to a demo of “United in Grief” from Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers. This was recorded sometime in May of 2020 but the song was leaked online on December 16, 2022.

The full leaked song can be listened to on Youtube.

For the “CHANEL Spring-Summer 2024 Haute Couture show”, Kendrick Lamar chose the chorus of this song to preview for the show, among a list of other musicians. He also changed the chorus lyrics to a clean version.

Kendrick might have used this as a way to promote his sixth album like he has in other ways such as Broccoli (Reincarnated) in the “Not Like Us” music video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H58vbez_m4E&pp=ygUMbm90IGxpa2UgdXMg

title: Like That

description.plain:
“Like That” sees Future and Metro Boomin enlist rap legend Kendrick Lamar for a hard-hitting track, where the two get a few things off their chest. Lamar takes it a step further, pronouncing himself alone as the best in the game.

The track samples Eazy-E’s 1988 hit single “Eazy-Duz-It” and the 1986 track “Everlasting Bass” by Rodney O & Joe Cooley. It also takes inspiration from E-40’s 1999 single “Look at Me,” which also sampled “Everlasting Bass.”

Future and Metro Boomin first performed “Like That” at Rolling Loud California during the duo’s set with Travis Scott on March 17, 2024, just days before the song’s release with WE DON’T TRUST YOU on March 22. The live rendition featured a different cut of Future’s verse not present on the album version.

title: King’s Dead

description.plain:
A star-studded collaboration. In his first single as the main credited artist since 2015, Jay Rock links up with Future, James Blake and Black Hippy partner and label mate, Kendrick Lamar.

The track first appeared on the official soundtrack for Marvel’s Black Panther making it the third single released for the album featuring Kendrick Lamar, following “All The Stars” with label-mate SZA but preceding “Pray for me” with The Weeknd.

However the track is also the first single from Jay Rock’s album  Redemption, the follow-up effort to his 2015 project 90059. The version that appears on Redemption however, omits the second half of the song.

Both Kendrick and Jay Rock would perform this song on each respective artist’s set at the TDE Championship Tour, while Jay Rock would appear during Kendrick’s set. Both performances did not contain the second half of the song.

The title refers to events in Black Panther, specifically to the supposed death of King T'Challa at the hands of the main antagonist, Killmonger. Kendrick makes direct reference to Killmonger, even rapping from his perspective and declaring himself king; an act Killmonger achieves following his fight with T'Challa. However the title might also refer to the actual death of King T'Chaka of Wakanda in the previous Captain America: Civil War.
Incidentally, the title of this song is a reference to the phrase “The king is dead, long live the king!,” which typically is used to mark the death of a previous king and celebrate the reign of the new one.

There are musical connections to the film in the song as well. The chanting heard at the end, for instance, can be heard throughout the movie. It is heard during the casino fight scene and again during the tribal battle at the end.

title: family ties

description.plain:
“family ties” finds cousins Baby Keem and Kendrick Lamar uniting for their first official collaboration after months of partnering under the pgLang imprint. Originally titled “Jump 2,” the first part of this now classic moshpit anthem was previewed back in March 2020 within the video teaser introducing pgLang; Baby Keem being the first artist partnering with Kendrick and Dave Free’s production company.

This is one of Kendrick Lamar’s very few musical appearances since the 2018 Black Panther movie soundtrack and is the first showcase of his alter ego, Oklama, introduced a week before the song’s release with a mysterious website.

On August 23, 2021, Keem announced the release of the single by posting the cover art, a family picture of the two cousins paying homage to the cover of Kendrick’s acclaimed 2012 debut album, good kid, m.A.A.d city.



Keem later shared two new snippets of the song and previewed a reversed preview of the Dave Free-directed music video, which released the same night as the song.

title: 30 For 30

description.plain:
“30 for 30” is the third track from SOS Deluxe: LANA. It samples Switch’s “I Call Your Name” and is the eighth collaboration between Kendrick Lamar and SZA.

The song is about setting boundaries, demanding authenticity, and dealing with emotional conflict. SZA and Kendrick assert their self-respect while calling out fake energy, ultimately choosing to prioritize their peace and personal growth.

title: GOOD CREDIT

description.plain:
“GOOD CREDIT” serves as the 15th track on Playboi Carti’s third studio album, MUSIC.

On September 22nd, 2024 the first signs of this collaboration would come when ‘Adam22’ (Founder of “No Jumper”) would claim that Playboi Carti was moving to Compton to shoot a music video with Kendrick Lamar (Though it was not yet confirmed).

Months later, in the hours leading up to the album’s release, Akademiks hinted at a feature on the album that was “Too Fye” to announce.
He stated;

“Buckle up y’all, that n—- talking that sh-t again”

Making an obvious reference to Kendrick Lamar’s now classic diss track “Not Like Us”, which has sparked controversy, as Kendrick took shots at Drake and won multiple Grammys, making it one of the most awarded rap songs in Grammy history.

Later, Playboi Carti revealed the album’s features via his spam account “opium_00pium”, except for one that was crossed out

After the delay of the album, the full tracklist was released via his spam account and confirmed Kendrick Lamar’s participation on the album.

In “GOOD CREDIT” Playboi Carti talks about his current status as an artist, flexing the money and style that come with it. he explains how many women are on him because of all that, also reflecting on his ongoing connection to the streets and his drug addiction.

The song features a verse from Kendrick Lamar, who, even though he appeared on previous tracks on the album like “MOJO JOJO” and “BACKD00R”, “GOOD CREDIT” is the only song where their collaboration is shown in the official album tracklist.

Kendrick emphasizes his image as an artist, saying the numbers and money he has don’t mean much to him, they don’t add any real value to him as a person or an artist. even though he drops references to his multiple pieces of jewelry, he focuses more on his brilliance and his position in the game right now, basically calling himself the greatest of all time.

title: range brothers

description.plain:
On “range brothers,” Baby Keem reunites with his cousin, Kendrick Lamar, to discuss numerous topics, including the financial success that comes with fame along with their tough upbringings, sexual prowess, and criticisms of disloyalty.

Like their first official collaboration, “family ties,” this track has multiple parts, which are marked by beat switches and shifts in their flows and cadences.

The track was initially leaked on September 8, 2021, two days prior to its official release. Lamar’s chorus on the third part of the song quickly became a viral meme.

title: The Hillbillies

description.plain:
“The Hillbillies” is a collaboration between Baby Keem and Kendrick Lamar on which they go back and forth, comparing themselves to Neymar and Messi respectively. The cousins rap about designer clothes, women, and their fame over an upbeat, Jersey club-inspired sample of Bon Iver’s “PDLIF.”

The song marks Kendrick’s second high-profile collaboration of 2023 following “AMERICA HAS A PROBLEM” with Beyoncé.

The song was unexpectedly released on the pgLang YouTube channel on May 30, 2023, alongside a music video directed by Neal Farmer. The song would later release on streaming platforms on June 5, 2023.



There is reason to believe that this track is a subliminal diss towards Drake.

Upon its release, fans noted similarities between Baby Keem’s flow on this track and Drake’s flow from his June 2022 song “Sticky,” with Keem himself calling the track “Baby Keem & Kendrick Lamar – The Hillbillies (Sticky Dub)” via Twitter. Some have interpreted the similarities between the two songs as a diss, potentially adding fuel to Drake and Kendrick’s longstanding beef, with others calling it a tribute.

The song’s music video also features a cameo from Tyler, the Creator, who teases the return of his Camp Flog Gnaw festival. Notably, Drake was booed off stage at the festival in 2019.

Days later, Kendrick performed his verse on Pusha T’s song “Nosetalgia” for the first time at a performance in Barcelona, Spain. Pusha notably beefed with Drake in 2018, culminating in the release of “The Story of Adidon” on which he revealed that Drake had a kid.

title: NILE

description.plain:
“NILE” serves as the tenth track on Beyoncé’s specially curated The Lion King soundtrack. The project dropped on July 19, 2019, along with the film’s worldwide theatrical release. The song would later make it onto the soundtrack for Beyonce’s 2020 film, Black Is King.

This is the second collaboration between Beyoncé and Kendrick Lamar. The two previously worked on April 2016’s “FREEDOM,” from Beyoncé’s award-winning album Lemonade. They also performed the song at the 2016 BET Awards.

title: The Mantra

description.plain:
Mike WiLL Made-It first teased “The Mantra” via Instragram on November 7, 2018. The track reunites Pharrell Williams and Kendrick Lamar, whose previous collaborations include 2017’s “Don’t Don’t Do It!” and “Kites,” as well as 2015’s “Alright” and 2012’s “good kid.”

“The Mantra” arrived three days ahead of the much-anticipated Creed II soundtrack release on November 16, 2018. It follows the release of another promotional single, “Kill ‘Em With Success” featuring Schoolboy Q and 2 Chainz.

Furthermore, this song marks Mike WiLL’s fourth collaboration with Pharrell and his seventh collaboration with Lamar.

title: Rapper Shit

description.plain: “Rapper shit” is an unreleased track by Ab-Soul and Kendrick Lamar. Produced by Tommy Black, this song features a sample from the song “Jesus Is My Lord” by Bob Wilson and Pauline Wilson. This song was originally supposed to be on Ab-Soul’s up an coming album at the time, Longterm Mentality. Unfortunately, the legendary collab never made an appearance as a main or bonus track and can only be found on Soundcloud and Youtube.

title: Kites

description.plain:
“Kites” is a multi-sectioned song with the album’s second Kendrick feature and the first time the band has worked with British rapper and political provocateur M.I.A.

The track uses the image of a kite flying in the skies to overcome borders and barriers, conveying messages of hope and tolerance in a time where there is very limited supply of either. This is significant in that “kites” is common slang for messages or packages delivered illegally in and out of prison, most likely derived from literal kites being used in the past. This implies that the artists involved view themselves as in a prison of sorts, trying to get their message heard.

title: The City

description.plain:
The first song on Game’s highly anticipated fourth studio album, The R.E.D Album. Released on August 19 in the UK and August 23 in the US, The R.E.D. has gained notoriety in the rap scene.

Although “The City” was not released as a single it has attained popularity among Game fans and on YouTube.

Produced by the excellent team of Cool and Dre, “The City” features Kendrick Lamar, a then-upcoming young rapper who hits the track with an intricate chorus and a bomb fourth verse. This was Lamar’s highest-profile collaboration at the time, but he has also featured on other songs including most recently “I Love Music” with Tech N9ne.

Game states that this song allowed him to show listeners how he “judges himself” and also as a sort of sum up of his previous albums.

title: Opps

description.plain:
“Opps”  (derived from the word ‘opposition’) is a term for cops or an opposite gang, against whom this song is directed. This marks the 2nd collaboration between California rappers Kendrick Lamar and Vince Staples, following 2017’s “Yeah Right”. The song also features South African rapper Yugen Blakrok.

The song was first heard in the Black Panther “Rise” TV Spot which followed Kendrick Lamar’s performance in the 2018 College Football National Championship Halftime Show.

The song was very fittingly used in the Black Panther movie scene where, T'Challa, Nakia, and Okoye pursued Ulysses Klaue and his men through the streets of Korea.
